;;一个人走过东京统一教会的一个分支。
;

;;日本政府已要求法院剥夺统一教会的地位，批评声日益增多;去年刺杀;前首相安倍晋三。

;

;如果东京地方法院接受请求，该教会（其成员通俗地称为;Moonies; – 将被剥夺它作为宗教公司的地位，并失去公司税和财产税以及货币产品收入税的豁免。

;

;但是，它可以继续以新的形式运营，使其能够招募成员媒体报道称，日本首相岸田文雄及其内阁在对该教会的活动进行了一年的调查后，本周决定要求法院采取行动，其中包括对教会成员施压的指控捐出巨额资金来寻求对自己“罪过”的宽恕。

;

;“它长期以来侵犯了人们的自由，阻止他们做出正确的决定，严重损害了人们的利益，扰乱了他们的生活， ”教育大臣森山雅人在提出请求前不久表示。

;

;教会在一份声明中表示，“政府根据左翼团体的偏见信息做出如此重要的决定，令人极其遗憾”旨在摧毁我们公司的律师”——显然是指全国反对精神销售律师网络，该网络代表那些声称因教会而遭受经济损失的人。

;

;一座前教堂一位化名在网上发帖的成员表示，政府的法律举措“已经等待很长时间了”。她补充道：“但这还不是结束。我们需要确保[法院]命令得到执行。”

;

;该教会的正式名称是“世界和平与统一家庭联合会”，在安倍于 2022 年 7 月被枪杀后，该教会受到了密切关注。这名男子表示，他对这位政治家与教会的关系感到不满。

;

;虽然安倍不是成员，但他曾向与教会有关的活动发出支持信息，据信该教会筹集了约 100 亿日元在日本每年花费 5500 万英镑，该教会声称在日本拥有 100,000 名活跃成员。

;

;他的祖父、前首相岸信介在帮助教会在 20 世纪 50 年代末在日本建立影响力方面发挥了重要作用。对抗共产主义和工会主义日益增长的影响力。

;

;暗杀安倍的嫌疑人山上哲也表示，他将责任归咎于教会;在他的母亲（一名成员）捐赠更多后，他的家庭破产了二十年前向该组织提供了超过 1 亿日元。

;

;在安倍去世后的几个月里，有报道称该教会;与政界人士关系密切;，其中包括大量属于执政党自民党的议员。

;

;作为回应，岸田命令党员;切断了与该教会的联系;，并启动了一项调查，重点调查该教会如何筹集资金为其在全球的活动提供资金。

;

;根据日本的宗教公司法，如果某个组织的行为“被明确认为对公共福利造成严重损害”，法院可以发布解散令。

;

;统一教会否认有任何不当行为，并承诺防止成员“过度”捐款.

;

;教育部花了近一年的时间;一个末日邪教;，其成员于 1995 年对东京地铁发动致命毒气袭击。奥姆真理教后来以两个不同的名称重新启动，并继续招募成员。

; Fri, 13 Oct 2023 17:52:01 +0800 Poorest countries should get $300bn a year from IMF to fight climate crisis, says Joseph Stiglitzhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/13/poorest-countries-should-get-300bn-a-year-to-fight-climate-crisis-says-joseph-stiglitz
;;2023-10-13T08:51:46Z;
;
;;2023 年 3 月马拉维布兰太尔被洪水淹没的房屋。
;

;贫穷国家应该诺贝尔奖获得者经济学家 ;约瑟夫·斯蒂格利茨;说过。

;

;斯蒂格利茨在马拉喀什举行的国际货币基金组织年会上接受《卫报》采访时表示，发展中国家需要与美国相当的国家 ;通货膨胀减少法案;——旨在促进绿色发展的一揽子赠款和补贴斯蒂格利茨表示，只有贫穷国家参与进来，对抗全球变暖的斗争才能取得胜利，但他们不可能提出类似的法案，他认为该法案成本高昂且存在缺陷但正在发挥作用。

;

;相反，他表示富裕国家应该支持每年设立 3000 亿美元（2460 亿英镑）的国际货币基金组织特别提款权 (SDR)，为全球绿色转型提供资金。

;

;斯蒂格利茨承认，在目前的僵局中，他的计划不可能在美国国会获得通过，但他表示，他将继续为此而努力。

;

;“随着气候变化的规模越来越令人印象深刻，我们，我们需要更大胆的事情。当时机成熟时，我们正在煎熬，有人说我们如何摆脱煎锅，这（年度特别提款权分配）就是这样做的一种方法。”

;

;需要额外的资金来帮助更贫困的人本周在摩洛哥举行的国际货币基金组织及其姊妹组织世界银行年会的议程上，各国应对全球变暖的影响和实现经济脱碳已成为重要议程。

;

;斯蒂格利茨世界银行首席经济学家表示，他欢迎为该行提供更多资金用于绿色项目贷款的计划，但表示需要采取更加雄心勃勃的方法。

;

;特别提款权是一种公认​​的国际储备资产，可以与硬通货，可用作信用额度。为应对新冠病毒大流行，国际货币基金组织于 2021 年发行了 6500 亿美元的特别提款权，被视为类似于量化宽松的货币创造形式。富裕国家不需要使用其拨款，并同意将部分特别提款权回收到国际货币基金组织的特别基金中，以支持贫穷国家。

;

;斯蒂格利茨谈到特别提款权时说：“基本上，它是在印钞票。这不会引发通货膨胀，但会带来变革。”

;

;这位美国经济学家表示，;欧盟;正在规划自己版本的《通胀削减法案》——但规模较小。 “发展中国家无法在任何规模上做到这一点。”

;

;“除非发展中国家和新兴市场减少排放，否则无论我们在美国和欧洲做什么虔诚的事，我们都将面临全球变暖。这些言论是关于对气候变化采取一些行动，然后你最需要的不是加入，而是疏远了他们。”

;

;该法案最初是由美国总统乔·拜登以 3700 亿美元的价格出售的。计划通过增加旨在实现净零排放的项目投资来重建该国的工业基础。斯蒂格利茨表示，刺激计划的实际规模可能为 1.5 兆美元。 “这是一种开放式税收抵免。好消息是我们得到了大量绿色投资。”

;

;斯蒂格利茨表示，他支持该法案，尽管该法案设计不佳，并且包含一些明显违反国际规则的“大规模保护主义”措施。

;;参观者在德国科隆的电脑游戏展上传递动视暴雪视频游戏《使命召唤》的广告。;

;英国竞争监管机构已批准微软以 690 亿美元（540 亿英镑）收购动视暴雪的交易，动视暴雪是《使命召唤》和《魔兽世界》等游戏的制造商，此举为两家公司完成收购铺平了道路。交易。

;

;竞争与市场管理局 (CMA) 移至 ;在 4 月份阻止了这项大型交易;，理由是担心 Xbox 游戏机制造商微软将主导新兴的云游戏市场。

;

;然而，;上个月该监管机构表示，; 一项修订后的交易，包括向动视暴雪的法国竞争对手育碧出售欧洲以外的云游戏版权，已经解决了其担忧，表明此次合作将获得批准。

;

;在周五的一份声明中CMA 首席执行官莎拉·卡德尔 (Sarah Cardell) 表示：“通过将动视暴雪的云流媒体版权出售给育碧，我们确保微软无法垄断这个重要且快速发展的市场。随着云游戏的发展，这种干预将确保人们获得更具竞争力的价格、更好的服务和更多选择。”

;

;与 ;动视暴雪;原定于 10 月 18 日到期。

;

;英国监管机构已;在欧盟同行通过了在微软对云游戏权利提供替代让步之后，美国竞争监管机构;未能获得法院禁令;来阻止它。联邦贸易委员会仍然反对该交易，但无法阻止微软和动视暴雪完成该交易。

;

; Fri, 13 Oct 2023 14:22:01 +0800 Ireland’s embrace of Zombie song at Rugby World Cup stirs debate over lyricshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/13/ireland-embrace-zombie-song-rugby-world-cup-stirs-debate-lyrics
;;2023-10-13T05:00:28Z;
;
;;爱尔兰球迷庆祝，其中一名高举爱尔兰国旗
;

;致命的爱尔兰共和军二十年后炸弹启发了其鲜明、令人毛骨悚然的歌词，《;the Cranberry;' 的歌曲 Zombie 经历了不太可能重生为橄榄球世界杯主题曲。

;

;爱尔兰球迷在法国各地的体育场里高声合唱，并希望在周六的一场;四分之一决赛在巴黎法兰西体育场对阵新西兰队。

;

;;多洛雷斯·奥赖尔丹 (Dolores O'Riordan) 的转变;将灼热的哀歌化为体育欢乐的赞歌，使这首歌重新流行起来，并引发了关于它是否仍然代表着对爱尔兰共和军暴力的否认的争论。

;

;这位出生于利默里克的歌手的歌词 – “这不是我，这不是我的家庭”——在;于 2018 年去世;。 “我们很高兴听到 Zombie 在 @spotify 上的流量刚刚超过 10 亿。多洛雷斯一定会欣喜若狂！感谢我们所有粉丝的大力支持。”乐队上周;推文;。

; < p>;爱尔兰橄榄球球迷高喊“这不是我”的热闹场景，伴随着体育场扩音系统播放的音乐，在 YouTube 上获得了数十万次观看，在 TikTok 上获得了数百万次观看。

; ;

;目前尚不清楚有多少粉丝了解或认可这首歌的信息。据信，大多数人跟着唱只是因为这首歌朗朗上口，并且已成为球队的非官方世界杯主题曲。

;

;即便如此，一些共和党人和爱尔兰共和军武装运动的支持者仍对这首歌的重新流行感到愤怒。社交媒体上的评论者对这首歌提及 1916 年复活节起义感到特别愤慨。

;

;“这是对爱尔兰共和党人和北方民族主义者的侮辱，”一位网友在推特上写道。 “这首歌嘲笑复活节周的男男女女，告诉‘六县’的民族主义人民，这一切都在他们的脑海里，”X（前推特）上的另一位人士说。一些人指责橄榄球迷是“西英国人”，这是对那些被认为对英国有亲和力的爱尔兰人的嘲讽。

;

;北爱尔兰社会民主工党 (SDLP) 领导人科勒姆·伊斯特伍德 (Colum Eastwood)，试图平息争议。他在推特上写道：“《僵尸》是一首反战歌曲，是在爱尔兰共和军在沃灵顿杀害两名儿童后创作的。” “别再试图把它变成它不是的东西。不要再假装反对爱尔兰共和军的暴行就等于支持英国的暴行。我们大多数人都反对两者。”

;

;据报道，2018 年奥赖尔丹去世后，利默里克曲棍球球迷是第一个采用“僵尸”作为体育歌曲的人。包括利默里克在内的省级橄榄球队明斯特的支持者也纷纷效仿，这种做法也传播到了国家队的球迷。

;

;关于僵尸的争议反映了沃尔夫·托恩斯 (Wolfe Tones) 一首赞美爱尔兰共和军 (IRA) 的歌曲引发的争议。 “哦，啊，上‘Ra’”——副歌 ;在一些音乐会和足球比赛中被人群采用;。

;

;爱尔兰总理利奥·瓦拉德卡 (Leo Varadkar) 表示，如果他参加世界杯，他会唱《Zombie》。 “这是一首很棒的歌曲，”他周三告诉广播电台 Newstalk。 “我认为这是一首我们都可以轻松唱的歌。这是一首反恐歌曲。这不是一首民族主义或工会主义歌曲。”

; Fri, 13 Oct 2023 13:52:01 +0800 ‘Corruption is not an African issue’: bank chief says it’s time to believe in the continent’s futurehttps://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/oct/13/corruption-not-african-issue-says-afdb-bank-chief-akinwumi-adesina-time-believe-in-continents-future
;;2023-10-13T05:00:29Z;
;
;;一位戴着眼镜、穿着西装、打着领结的非洲男子摆出姿势拍照
;

;非洲一位非洲大陆领先的金融人物表示，西方老龄化经济体拥有未来的劳动力，他还表示，是时候抛弃有关腐败和风险的神话了。

;

;在此前的独家采访中周末在摩洛哥举行的世界银行会议上，阿金乌米·阿德西纳 (Akinwumi Adesina) 表示，人们对非洲经济前景的信心重新抬头，并抨击了负面成见，并补充说，“有充分理由保持乐观”。

;

;现在，他的第二个五年任期已经过半了。这位尼日利亚前农业部长在非洲开发银行 (AfDB) 行长任期一年内表示，非洲大陆的人口优势、不断扩大的中产阶级和巨大的投资机会意味着转变正在发生。

;
;
;

;2008 年导致世界崩溃的全球金融危机并非发生在非洲。我们没有华尔街

;
;
;

;“而且不久之前 - 我们已经厌倦了处于价值链的底部，”阿德西纳说。 “通往贫困的最快途径是出口原材料，但通向财富的高速公路是通过全球价值链，为你拥有的一切（从石油、天然气、矿物、金属和食品）增加价值。我们必须增加价值。

;

;;“;问题是我们必须进行正确的投资；我们必须确保治理环境是正确的；我们必须确保激励措施是正确的。非洲必须采取立场，不再处于底层，而是处于顶层。”

;

;非洲开发银行成立于 1964 年，是非洲唯一的;AAA 级金融机构;，专注于 Adesina 所说的“击掌”：实现普遍用电、提高生活质量、工业化、粮食自给自足，并整合非洲大陆54个国家，创造更大、更高效的市场。

;

;“我认为，除非你能养活自己，否则你无法自豪地实现发展，”他说。

; <图 data-media-id="97643e034388f03f6713da297651c7fb3fa267ba">; ; ; ;

;他说，金额破纪录过去几年吸引的国际投资者表明人们对该银行在整个非洲，特别是 37 个低收入国家快速发展的能力重新产生了信任。

;

;“该银行的 81 名股东提供了到 2019 年底，该银行的资本从 930 亿美元增加到 2,080 亿美元（760 亿英镑到 1,710 亿英镑）——这是该银行历史上最高的资本增幅。这是及时的，因为我们几乎没有想到我们会进入新冠病毒的世界。

;

;“因此，这一增加使我们能够很快为应对新冠病毒危机提供 100 亿美元的紧急支持设施，以应对新冠肺炎疫情。”当全球粮食危机源自俄罗斯乌克兰战争时，非洲立即做出反应。我们启动了一项价值 15 亿美元的紧急粮食生产设施，以缓解导致非洲粮食危机的全球地缘政治危机。”

;
;
;

;我是一个永远的乐观主义者……看看这些数字：到 2030 年，非洲人口将达到 17.2 亿。这比中国还多，比印度还多

;
;
;

;但他确实希望国际金融体系的结构更加公平，以便非洲各国与发达国家一样有平等的机会获得储备和流动性。阿德西纳将在本周末的世界银行峰会上呼吁公平。

;

;“对我们来说非常重要的是特别提款权问题。非洲需要更多的资源来为气候融资，但实际上现有的资源还不够。我们现在摆在桌面上的是国际货币基金组织的特别提款权。但当它们发行时，发行了6500亿美元，非洲获得了330亿美元。 4.5%，不太好。欧洲的一些小国家得到了更多，这是不公平、不包容的。”由于国际货币基金组织有 190 个成员国，非洲 54 个国家本应更接近获得 25% 的特别提款权。

;

;“非洲国家元首要求从这些国家重新调拨 1000 亿美元Adesina 说，他相信这可能是真正取得进展的关键。

;

;“我们可能会考虑稍微调整一下。并称之为支持发展振兴。这也是特别提款权。”

;

;;2023-10-13T04:00:28Z;
;
;;孩子们吃学校餐。
;

;欧洲各地的孩子必须至少获得一份营养学校餐专家联盟表示，如果政府想要解决不断上升的肥胖率、预防慢性疾病和减少社会不平等，那么这一天就是这一天。

;

;欧洲近三分之一的小学学龄儿童;要么超重，要么肥胖;，而欧盟近四分之一的儿童面临;贫困或社会排斥;。

;

;随着生活成本危机现在使欧洲大陆的许多家庭陷入崩溃的境地，四年期欧盟成员国-资助的倡议重点关注健康饮食，并表示迫切需要采取行动，确保所有欧洲儿童每天至少能吃到一顿健康的膳食。

;

;Peter Defranceschi，;SchoolFood4Change 项目; 说：“我认为，一旦你说每个孩子每天都需要获得健康的学校膳食 - 无论他们是富有、贫穷、处于贫困社区或任何地方 - 这是一个在欧洲非常有意义的最低标准。

;

;“这不是左或右，或自由或绿色，这确实是一件明智的事情。”< /p>;

;专家们表示，学校供餐可以成为“广泛社会层面系统性变革的催化剂”，他们正在与 12 个欧盟国家 16 个城市和地区的 3,000 多所学校和 600,000 名学童合作。

;

; p>;

;

;;相关：;;让免费学校餐成为一项普遍权利并不需要花费太多 |拉里·埃利奥特;

;
;

;整个非洲大陆的情况差异很大：虽然芬兰、爱沙尼亚和瑞典等国家保证儿童获得免费餐食，但其他国家传统上基本上不提供免费餐食，例如如挪威和荷兰。 The experts want to see free meals made available for all children from poorer backgrounds, who are also more likely to have missed out on breakfast.

;

;“With Ukraine, food prices went up further, so you've had food price inflation and some parents not being able to buy proper food for their kids or to pay for their food at school,” said Defranceschi, who also leads the Global CityFood Program at the local governments for sustainability (ICLEI) network.

;

;“Apart from that, there are many kids going to school without breakfast. If the school doesn't serve any food, then sometimes they just sit there without having a proper meal, which makes it difficult for them to concentrate.”

;

;Manuel Franco, a professor of epidemiology and public health at the ;University of Alcalá near Madrid; and the ;Johns Hopkins School of Public Health;, who serves as one of the project's advisers, says countries need to stop looking at healthy school meals as an expense and instead view them as a vital tool for tackling future health crises and reducing social inequalities.

;

;“The consequences of eating an unhealthy, low-quality diet are to be seen in children and adolescents – and are seen more often in under-served communities and vulnerable populations – and this is a problem in the long-run for our health and for our wellbeing,” he said.

;

;“We know that in the long run that adults who have a poor diet will develop more diseases like diabetes and cancer.我们需要翻转硬币，看看每天为我们人口中的每个儿童和青少年投资 7 欧元就是我们正在投资的钱。 It's not an expenditure.”

;

;In almost every country, Franco said, children living in lower-income areas have a lower-quality diet than their more affluent peers. They are also subject to food insecurity because their parents often don't have enough money to provide them with healthy and nutritious meals on a daily basis.

;

;“Within that picture, children aged one to 18 being able to eat at least once a day in a school or educational centre would be a fantastic tool, or public health intervention, in order to have higher-quality diets,” he said. While free school meals for everyone, rich and poor, would be terrific, he added, “we should always be making sure that those children who need school meals the most are the ones who get them for free”.

;

;While school meals and health policies are matters for individual EU countries, Franco points out that under the ;European Child Guarantee;, adopted two years ago, the bloc's members are meant to be tackling child poverty and social exclusion and guaranteeing basic rights such as healthcare and education. One of the guarantee's key objectives is “free education (including school-based activities and at least one healthy meal each school day)”.

;

;Failure to act now, say Franco and his colleagues, will only yield health problems for countless individuals and more expenses for the taxpayers of the future. An ;online petition urging “a healthy school meal for every child in every school”; – which was ;presented to MEPs in Brussels on Tuesday; – has already attracted almost 55,000 signatures.

; Fri, 13 Oct 2023 12:52:01 +0800 New Zealand election 2023: Labour and National make last-ditch pleas to voters on eve of pollhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/13/new-zealand-election-2023-nz-labour-chris-hipkins-national-christopher-luxon

;
;;New Zealand prime minister and Labour leader Chris Hipkins (left) and National leader Christopher Luxon
;

;The leaders of New Zealand's two major political parties have made a last ditch effort to sway votes in their favour on the final day of campaigning before the country's general election.

;

;The leaders clashed in their most heated debate yet – the last of the campaign, which aired on TVNZ on Thursday night. In his final message, Labour's Chris Hipkins warned the public that a vote for the opposition would bake in poverty and see action on climate change go backwards.

;

;“In tough times it's natural to look for change, but change has consequences – if Christopher Luxon wins, you lose,” Hipkins said. “There is a better way – Labour will help you with the cost of living and grow the economy.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;Racism, threats and home invasions: candidates face abuse on New Zealand's campaign trail;

;
;

;National's Christopher Luxon used his last message to promise to reduce the cost of living, provide tax relief, restore law and order and improve healthcare and education.

;

;“Kiwis know we can be so much better than this – National has the team, energy and positive plans to take us forward,” Luxon said.

;

;Polling suggests the governing Labour party is set to be ousted by the right bloc in Saturday's election, even as predictions of a green wave for Labour's traditional coalition partner, the Green party, may result in a record 15 seats in parliament.民意调查显示，即使绿党预计拥有席位，工党也不太可能达到执政所需的 61 个席位。 Te Pāti Māori – Labour's other likely coalition partner on the left – is also struggling to gain traction.

;

;While hope may not be entirely lost for the left, after Labour ;gained some support ;in recent polls, it may be too little too late, says Lara Greaves, an associate professor of political science at Victoria University of Wellington.

;

;“It's not clear to what extent voter turnout will play a role, and it's not clear whether underestimating Labour at the polls will play out as well … there are so many factors that it feels like a close one,” Greaves said.

;

;New Zealand's predicted shift to the right would end Labour's six years in office, which oversaw the Covid-19 pandemic years, the Christchurch mosque attacks and the Whakaari volcano eruption, and would firmly draw a line under Jacinda Ardern's era of politics.

;

;The party was voted into power on a wave of ;“Jacindamania;” in 2017 and required the Greens and the minor New Zealand First party to secure its victory under New Zealand's electoral system – a version of the mixed-member proportional (MMP) format. Then, in 2020, off the back of its world-leading pandemic response, it was returned to power in a landslide – giving it the biggest mandate of any New Zealand government in nearly 30 years.

;

;In the years since, the rising cost of living and post-pandemic malaise has translated into dissatisfaction with the political status quo, and the party no-longer has Ardern's extraordinary star-power to bolster its appeal, after her ;shock resignation in January;.

;

;But Labour's misfortune has not translated into a surge of support for the centre-right National Party. Polling in the lead up to the election has revealed; confidence in the centrist parties has slipped; away in favour of the minor parties. The majority of voters ;feel the country is on the wrong track;, reversing ;two decades of consistent public satisfaction; under both Labour and National governments.

;

;While that spells good news for parties on the left such as the Greens, which is hoovering up votes from those who want to see stronger action on climate change and transformative investment in the social security net, it has also resulted in a boost for the more radical right-wing and populist parties.

;

;“I would say it is bittersweet for the Greens because if the left loses they are not part of the government, but they will have a lot of new MPS, a lot of new talent, a lot of future ministers there that they can build up and create quite a basis for opposition,” Greaves said.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Shocking silence' over climate crisis in New Zealand election campaign draws criticism;

;
;

;But ultimately, the winner this election may be ;Winston Peters; and his populist New Zealand First party “because they will hold quite a bit of power,” she said. Support for New Zealand First – which was ousted in the 2020 election – has jumped in the last few weeks of the election campaign.

;

;Polling suggests National will need to rely on both the libertarian-right Act party and New Zealand First (which has ruled out working with Labour again) in order to form a government, which could result in a much more conservative government than New Zealand is used to.

;

;What the relationship between the three parties will look like in practice is anyone's guess, Greaves said. And New Zealanders could be in for a wait – in previous elections where Peters has held that balance of power, he has drawn out negotiations for weeks, Greaves said.

;

;“If you look at 1996, Winston Peters made us all wait for two months … people were putting up Christmas decorations … in 2017 it took him four weeks … so it could be quite some time.”

;

;The federal judge in the criminal case about Donald Trump's retention of classified documents rebuked prosecutors for “wasting the court's time” on Thursday with their sudden request to partly restrict the lawyer for one of Trump's co-defendants.

;

;US district judge Aileen Cannon abruptly postponed the hearing after getting the request – which came after prosecutors had first said they would not seek disqualification.

;

;“I do want to admonish the government for frankly wasting the court's time,” Cannon said. She added she was “disappointed” that David Harbach, one of the prosecutors, had raised the request without warning, and without citing supporting cases from the southern district of Florida.

;

;The hearing was the second in a pair of proceedings scheduled so Trump's co-defendants, Walt Nauta and Carlos De Oliveira, could be told of their lawyers' prior ;representation of witnesses during the grand jury investigation; who could testify against them at trial.

;

;Trump and Nauta were charged in an indictment alleging the illegal retention of national defense documents at Trump's ;Mar-a-Lago; resort and obstruction of justice. With De Oliveira they were charged on additional obstruction counts in a superseding indictment unsealed in July.

;

;The prosecutors in the office of special counsel Jack Smith had asked for conflict-of-interest hearings for Nauta's lawyer Stanley Woodward and De Oliveira's lawyer John Irving, due to the fact they might be constrained at trial because of divided loyalties to their current and former clients.

;

;The complication emerged at the hearing for Nauta, when prosecutors said they could not be sure how Woodward might cross-examine “Trump Employee 4”, identified by the Guardian as the IT director of Mar-a-Lago, Yuscil Taveras.

;

;Taveras is of special interest because Woodward initially represented him during the grand jury investigation. When prosecutors told him he was a target for charges, Taveras retained a new lawyer – not paid by Trump's PAC – and changed his sworn testimony.

;

;The prosecutors revealed at the hearing that they now intended to call Taveras as a witness, and told the judge they believed Woodward should be precluded from engaging in cross-examination, or be allowed to call into question his credibility during closing arguments to the jury.

;

;The cross-examination concern had been previously raised in court filings. But asking to preclude Woodward from doing closing arguments was a new request, and it seemed to irritate Cannon, who pressed Harbach on why it was being raised for the first time at the hearing.

;

;Woodward himself raised an objection to prosecutors' arguments, saying that the fact he had represented Taveras did not mean he could not attack his credibility at trial – and that he was not comfortable about Nauta making a decision on a potential conflict of interest until his role at trial could be resolved.

;

;Woodward added that he had not come prepared to litigate that point because it had only just been raised by Harbach in court on Thursday. The judge agreed, particularly after Harbach acknowledged he did not have supporting cases from the eleventh circuit, which are binding.

;

;Earlier, at the first of the pair of conflicts hearings, De Oliveira told the judge he wanted to keep his Trump PAC-funded lawyer, John Irving, even though Irving had ;previously represented three witnesses; who could be called by prosecutors to testify against him at trial.

;

;“I want to continue to move forward with Mr Irving,” De Oliveira affirmed.

;

;The potential conflicts might have seemed less pressing for De Oliveira, mainly because Irving had decided beforehand that cross-examination of those witnesses would be done by his co-counsel, Donnie Murrell.

;

;The larger issue for De Oliveira appeared to be whether he grasped the full extent of what retaining a potentially conflicted lawyer could mean. De Oliveira struggled to explicate in his own words what he understood, and earlier told the judge he could read English better than he could write.

;

;De Oliveira's language skills have been a topic of discussion inside the Trump legal team for months, according to people familiar with the matter. He told the judge that when he emigrated from Portugal at 17, he had not graduated high school, and never completed his secondary education.

;The Republican congressman Steve Scalise has said he is ending his bid to become the US House speaker after failing to secure enough votes to win the gavel.

;
;

;
;

;“I just shared with my colleagues that I'm withdrawing my name as a candidate for speaker-designee,” Scalise said as he emerged from the closed-door meeting at the Capitol, where he first informed fellow Republican colleagues of his decision.

;

;Scalise, ;a hardline conservative; representing Louisiana, said the Republican majority “still has to come together and is not there”.

;

;“There are still some people that have their own agendas,” Scalise said. “And I was very clear, we have to have everybody put their agendas on the side and focus on what this country needs.”

;

;Next steps are uncertain as the House ;is now essentially closed;, while the Republican majority tries to elect a speaker after a small number of them voted alongside Democrats to oustKevin McCarthy from the job.

;

;The standoff over the speakership, which was sparked by the hard-right Florida congressman Matt Gaetz, has left congressional business at a standstill, with many Republican lawmakers furious at the degree of division within their party – and how voters are likely to judge them for their inability to govern.

;

;Scalise's decision to end his bid followed a day of meetings that moved him; ;no closer to overcoming the entrenched divisions imperiling his quest for the speakership.

;

;House Republicans had raised a number of concerns with Scalise's candidacy, among them that, as the No 2 House Republican, he doesn't represent institutional change, that he lacks a unifying vision for the conference, or that his ​battle with blood cancer would make it difficult for him to lead the chamber.

;

;Many hardliners taking their cues from Donald Trump have dug in for a prolonged fight to replace ;McCarthy; after his ;historic ouster from the job;, saying Scalise is not the replacement they will support. They argue that he is no better choice than McCarthy and should be focusing on his health.

;

;Earlier in the day, supporters of the congressman Jim Jordan of Ohio, the chair of the judiciary committee, said they would continue to push for his candidacy.

;

;Action is needed to fund the government before a potential federal shutdown in a month.议员们还希望国会发表强有力的声明，支持以色列与哈马斯的战争，但两党决议因众议院陷入僵局而被搁置。 The White House is expected to soon ask for money for Israel, Ukraine and the backfill of the US weapons stockpile.

;

;The situation is not entirely different from that of the start of the year, when McCarthy faced a similar backlash from a different group of ;far-right holdouts; who ultimately gave their votes to elect him speaker, then engineered his historic downfall.
